Key Arguments: The definitions of misinformation and disinformation in the Bill are ambiguous and difficult to apply.
There is insufficient detail about the governance and oversight of the proposed law, leading to potential over-censorship by platforms.
The legislation could infringe on Australians' freedom of speech and expression.
Existing laws already prohibit incitement to discrimination, hostility, or violence, making additional legislation unnecessary.
Main Themes: Potential overreach of government and platforms
Notable Quotes: Who is going to be the ultimate arbiter in deciding whether the information in question is 'false, misleading or deceptive'?
This could lead to a version of 1984/Stalin repression-style thought policing where any expressed thoughts would be censored if they are suspected to lead to any harm to any end-user.

Our grave concern is that the proposed law will make it harder for Australians to criticise their government and government-subsidised institutions and even, each other, when they disagree with alternative views.
Silencing is not an answer and will only create a greater divide between the public and the government by generating even more mistrust within the general community.
